verses.sanskrit_text:
श्रीभगवानुवाच।
इमं विवस्वते योगं प्रोक्तवानहमव्ययम्।
विवस्वान्मनवे प्राह मनुरिक्ष्वाकवेऽब्रवीत्।।
verses.transliteration:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
imaṁ vivasvate yogaṁ proktavān aham avyayam
vivasvān manave prāha manur ikṣvākave 'bravīt
verses.translation: The Supreme Lord said: I taught this imperishable Yoga to Vivasvan (the sun-god); Vivasvan taught it to Manu (the progenitor of mankind); and Manu, in turn, told it to Ikshvaku (King Ikshvaku).
verses.commentary: Krishna begins the fourth chapter by revealing the ancient and timeless nature of his teachings. He establishes a lineage of this 'imperishable Yoga' (knowledge of Karma Yoga), tracing it back to the sun-god Vivasvan. By doing so, he is not just giving Arjuna personal advice but is revealing a universal truth that has been passed down through ages. This establishes the authority and authenticity of his teachings.

verses.sanskrit_text:
एवं परम्पराप्राप्तमिमं राजर्षयो विदुः।
स कालेनेह महता योगो नष्टः परन्तप।।
verses.transliteration:
evaṁ paramparā-prāptam imaṁ rājarṣayo viduḥ
sa kāleneha mahatā yogo naṣṭaḥ parantapa
verses.translation: Thus, the royal sages received this knowledge through a continuous lineage. But in the course of time, O chastiser of enemies, this Yoga was lost.
verses.commentary: Krishna explains why he is teaching this ancient knowledge to Arjuna. He states that the 'paramparā' (lineage) was broken, and this 'Yoga' was lost to humanity. This verse justifies his current role as the teacher and the need for a new revelation of this eternal knowledge to the world, through Arjuna. It also highlights the fragility of spiritual wisdom when it is not properly passed down.

verses.sanskrit_text:
स एवायं मया तेऽद्य योगः प्रोक्तः पुरातनः।
भक्तोऽसि मे सखा चेति रहस्यं ह्येतदुत्तमम्।।
verses.transliteration:
sa evāyaṁ mayā te 'dya yogaḥ proktaḥ purātanaḥ
bhakto 'si me sakhā ceti rahasyaṁ hy etad uttamam
verses.translation: That same ancient Yoga has been taught to you by Me today, because you are my devotee and my friend. This is the supreme secret.
verses.commentary: Krishna explains why he is choosing to reveal this 'supreme secret' to Arjuna. The reason is not intellectual prowess but a personal relationship based on 'bhakti' (devotion) and 'sakhā' (friendship). This verse highlights that spiritual knowledge is not just theoretical but requires a personal connection and devotion to the teacher. This is the foundation of the path of 'Bhakti Yoga', which is intertwined with the path of Karma Yoga in the Gita.

verses.sanskrit_text:
अर्जुन उवाच।
अपरं भवतो जन्म परं जन्म विवस्वतः।
कथमेतद्विजानीयां त्वमादौ प्रोक्तवानिति।।
verses.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca
aparaṁ bhavato janma paraṁ janma vivasvataḥ
katham etad vijānīyāṁ tvam ādau proktavān iti
verses.translation: Arjuna said: Your birth is recent, but the birth of Vivasvan is ancient. How can I understand that you taught this in the beginning?
verses.commentary: Arjuna, from his human perspective, sees a chronological contradiction in Krishna's words. He knows Krishna as his contemporary and friend, so he questions how Krishna could have taught an ancient being like Vivasvan. This question shows Arjuna's limited, human understanding and sets the stage for Krishna to reveal his divine, transcendental nature.

verses.sanskrit_text:
श्रीभगवानुवाच।
बहूनि मे व्यतीतानि जन्मानि तव चार्जुन।
तान्यहं वेद सर्वाणि न त्वं वेत्थ परन्तप।।
verses.transliteration:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
bahūni me vyatītāni janmāni tava cārjuna
tāny ahaṁ veda sarvāṇi na tvaṁ vettha parantapa
verses.translation: The Supreme Lord said: Many births of mine and yours have passed, O Arjuna. I know them all, but you do not, O chastiser of enemies.
verses.commentary: Krishna directly answers Arjuna's question by stating the fundamental difference between himself and all other beings. He explains that while both he and Arjuna have had countless past lives, Krishna remembers them all while Arjuna does not. This establishes Krishna's identity as the Supreme Being, who is beyond the limitations of time and memory, and therefore, fully capable of being the eternal teacher.

verses.sanskrit_text:
अजोऽपि सन्नव्ययात्मा भूतानामीश्वरोऽपि सन्।
प्रकृतिं स्वामधिष्ठाय संभवाम्यात्ममायया।।
verses.transliteration:
ajo 'pi sann avyayātmā bhūtānām īśvaro 'pi san
prakṛtiṁ svām adhiṣṭhāya saṁbhavāmy ātma-māyayā
verses.translation: Though I am unborn, My self is imperishable, and I am the Lord of all beings, I manifest Myself by My own divine power, taking on My own material nature.
verses.commentary: Krishna explains the mystery of his birth and manifestation. He states that unlike ordinary beings who are born out of karma, he is 'ajaḥ' (unborn) and 'avyaya-ātmā' (imperishable). He takes birth in the material world, not out of necessity, but out of his own free will, using his 'ātma-māyayā' (divine power). This is a foundational teaching that distinguishes Krishna as the supreme, transcendental being, not just an ordinary human.

verses.sanskrit_text:
यदा यदा हि धर्मस्य ग्लानिर्भवति भारत।
अभ्युत्थानमधर्मस्य तदात्मानं सृजाम्यहम्।।
verses.transliteration:
yadā yadā hi dharmasya glānir bhavati bhārata
abhyutthānam adharmasya tadātmānaṁ sṛjāmy aham
verses.translation: Whenever righteousness declines and unrighteousness prevails, O Bharata, I manifest Myself.
verses.commentary: This is one of the most famous and central verses of the Gita. Krishna explains the reason for his repeated incarnations. He states that he manifests whenever 'dharma' (righteousness) declines and 'adharma' (unrighteousness) rises. This verse provides a cosmic and ethical purpose for Krishna's appearance, and it justifies the battle of Kurukshetra as a necessary event for the restoration of righteousness.

verses.sanskrit_text:
परित्राणाय साधूनां विनाशाय च दुष्कृताम्।
धर्मसंस्थापनार्थाय सम्भवामि युगे युगे।।
verses.transliteration:
paritrāṇāya sādhūnāṁ vināśāya ca duṣkṛtām
dharma-saṁsthāpanārthāya saṁbhavāmi yuge yuge
verses.translation: To protect the righteous, to annihilate the wicked, and to re-establish righteousness, I manifest Myself from age to age.

word_meanings.meaning: for the purpose of re-establishing righteousness

verses.commentary: Krishna explicitly states the threefold purpose of his incarnation. He comes to 'protect the righteous' ('sādhūnām'), 'annihilate the wicked' ('duṣkṛtām'), and 're-establish righteousness' ('dharma-saṁsthāpana-arthāya'). This verse is a direct justification for the war. Krishna is essentially telling Arjuna that his duty to fight is not just a personal one but a divine mission that is part of a larger cosmic plan to restore order and justice.

verses.sanskrit_text:
जन्म कर्म च मे दिव्यमेवं यो वेत्ति तत्त्वतः।
त्यक्त्वा देहं पुनर्जन्म नैति मामेति सोऽर्जुन।।
verses.transliteration:
janma karma ca me divyam evaṁ yo vetti tattvataḥ
tyaktvā dehaṁ punar janma naiti mām eti so 'rjuna
verses.translation: One who knows My divine birth and action in truth, O Arjuna, is not born again upon leaving the body, but attains Me.
verses.commentary: Krishna explains the reward for understanding his divine nature. He states that one who understands the 'divine birth and action' ('divyam janma karma') of God is freed from the cycle of rebirth and attains God. This verse links the path of knowledge and devotion to the ultimate goal of liberation. It provides a powerful motivation for Arjuna to not just fight, but to do so with the knowledge of Krishna's supreme nature.

verses.sanskrit_text:
वीतरागभयक्रोधा मन्मया मामुपाश्रिताः।
बहवो ज्ञानतपसा पूता मद्भावमागताः।।
verses.transliteration:
vīta-rāga-bhaya-krodhā man-mayā mām upāśritāḥ
bahavo jñāna-tapasā pūtā mad-bhāvam āgatāḥ
verses.translation: Many who were free from attachment, fear, and anger, absorbed in Me, and having taken refuge in Me, have been purified by the austerity of knowledge and have attained My state of being.

word_meanings.meaning: free from attachment, fear, and anger

verses.commentary: Krishna provides historical evidence for the effectiveness of his teachings. He states that many have achieved liberation by following the path he is describing. The three key qualities for this path are freedom from 'rāga' (attachment), 'bhaya' (fear), and 'krodha' (anger). He also mentions 'jñāna-tapasā' (austerity of knowledge), which shows that the path is not easy but requires discipline. This gives Arjuna reassurance that the path he is being shown is a tested and proven one.

verses.sanskrit_text:
ये यथा मां प्रपद्यन्ते तांस्तथैव भजाम्यहम्।
मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः।।
verses.transliteration:
ye yathā māṁ prapadyante tāṁs tathaiva bhajāmy aham
mama vartmānuvartante manuṣyāḥ pārtha sarvaśaḥ
verses.translation: In whatever way people surrender to Me, I reciprocate accordingly. All people, O son of Pritha, follow My path in every way.
verses.commentary: This verse is a cornerstone of the Gita's message of divine reciprocation. Krishna states that he responds to everyone's devotion 'yathā' (in whatever way) they approach him. This implies that there is no single, rigid path to God. He also states that all paths ultimately lead to him, showing his all-encompassing nature. This teaching is a powerful message of divine grace and inclusion, making his teachings accessible to all.

verses.sanskrit_text:
काङ्क्षन्तः कर्मणां सिद्धिं यजन्त इह देवताः।
क्षिप्रं हि मानुषे लोके सिद्धिर्भवति कर्मजा।।
verses.transliteration:
kāṅkṣantaḥ karmaṇāṁ siddhiṁ yajanta iha devatāḥ
kṣipraṁ hi mānuṣe loke siddhir bhavati karmajā
verses.translation: Those who desire the fruits of their actions worship the demigods in this world, for success born of action happens quickly in the human world.
verses.commentary: Krishna provides a sociological observation. He states that people who are attached to the 'siddhiṁ' (success) and quick results of their actions tend to worship the 'devatāḥ' (demigods). This is a natural human tendency to seek immediate, tangible results. Krishna is not condemning this but is explaining that it is a lower form of worship driven by desire. This is another way he is trying to guide Arjuna toward a higher, more selfless goal.

verses.sanskrit_text:
चातुर्वर्ण्यं मया सृष्टं गुणकर्मविभागशः।
तस्य कर्तारमपि मां विद्ध्यकर्तारमव्ययम्।।
verses.transliteration:
cātur-varṇyaṁ mayā sṛṣṭaṁ guṇa-karma-vibhāgaśaḥ
tasya kartāram api māṁ viddhy akartāram avyayam
verses.translation: The four divisions of human society were created by Me, according to the distinction of their qualities and actions. Although I am the creator of this, know me to be the non-doer and imperishable.

word_meanings.meaning: according to the distinction of qualities and actions

verses.commentary: Krishna explains the origin and purpose of the 'four divisions of society' (cātur-varṇyaṁ), which are based on 'guṇa' (qualities) and 'karma' (actions), not birth. He states that he is the creator of this system, but at the same time, he is the 'akartāram' (non-doer) because he is detached from the process. This verse is a profound philosophical statement on the nature of divine action: God acts, but he is not bound by his actions. This is the ideal Krishna is holding up for Arjuna.

verses.sanskrit_text:
न मां कर्माणि लिम्पन्ति न मे कर्मफले स्पृहा।
इति मां योऽभिजानाति कर्मभिर्न स बध्यते।।
verses.transliteration:
na māṁ karmāṇi limpanti na me karma-phale spṛhā
iti māṁ yo 'bhijānāti karmabhir na sa badhyate
verses.translation: Actions do not taint Me, nor do I have any craving for the results of action. One who knows Me thus in truth is also not bound by actions.
verses.commentary: Krishna provides the key to freedom from 'karma' (action). He states that he is not bound by his actions because he has no desire for their results. He explains that a person who understands this truth about God can also act without being bound. This teaching links 'Karma Yoga' directly to 'Bhakti Yoga', showing that the path to liberation is not just action but is action performed with the knowledge and devotion of God's detached nature.

verses.sanskrit_text:
एवं ज्ञात्वा कृतं कर्म पूर्वैरपि मुमुक्षुभिः।
कुरु कर्मैव तस्मात्त्वं पूर्वैः पूर्वतरं कृतम्।।
verses.transliteration:
evaṁ jñātvā kṛtaṁ karma pūrvair api mumukṣubhiḥ
kuru karmaiva tasmāt tvaṁ pūrvaiḥ pūrvataraṁ kṛtam
verses.translation: Knowing this, the ancient seekers of liberation also performed action. Therefore, you should also perform action, as it was performed by the ancients in earlier times.
verses.commentary: Krishna provides historical and ethical justification for his teaching. He tells Arjuna that the ancient 'mumukṣubhiḥ' (seekers of liberation) also performed their duty with a detached mindset. He is telling Arjuna that he is not being asked to do something new or radical, but to follow the path of righteousness that was followed by his own ancestors. This appeal to tradition is a powerful way to convince Arjuna to fight.

verses.sanskrit_text:
किं कर्म किमकर्मेति कवयोऽप्यत्र मोहिताः।
तत्ते कर्म प्रवक्ष्यामि यज्ज्ञात्वा मोक्ष्यसेऽशुभात्।।
verses.transliteration:
kiṁ karma kim akarmeti kavayo 'py atra mohitāḥ
tat te karma pravakṣyāmi yaj jñātvā mokṣyase 'śubhāt
verses.translation: Even the intelligent are bewildered as to what is action and what is inaction. Therefore, I will now explain to you the nature of action, by knowing which you will be freed from all evil.
verses.commentary: Krishna acknowledges the difficulty of distinguishing between 'karma' (action) and 'akarma' (inaction). He states that this is a subtle point that has confused even the 'kavayaḥ' (intelligent). He promises to provide the definitive explanation for this, and by doing so, he will free Arjuna from all 'aśubhāt' (evil). This verse shows that Krishna is not just giving an opinion but is revealing a deep, spiritual truth.

verses.sanskrit_text:
कर्मणो ह्यपि बोद्धव्यं बोद्धव्यं च विकर्मणः।
अकर्मणश्च बोद्धव्यं गहना कर्मणो गतिः।।
verses.transliteration:
karmaṇo hy api boddhavyaṁ boddhavyaṁ ca vikarmaṇaḥ
akarmaṇaś ca boddhavyaṁ gahanā karmaṇo gatiḥ
verses.translation: The nature of action is to be understood, also the nature of prohibited action, and the nature of inaction. The path of action is indeed difficult to understand.
verses.commentary: Krishna expands on the difficulty of understanding action. He states that one must understand three things: 'karma' (prescribed action), 'vikarma' (prohibited action), and 'akarma' (inaction). He calls the path of action 'gahanā' (profound or mysterious) because it is not as simple as performing a physical act. This verse sets the stage for a detailed explanation of these three concepts, which is crucial for Arjuna to overcome his 'moha' (delusion).

verses.sanskrit_text:
कर्मण्यकर्म यः पश्येदकर्मणि च कर्म यः।
स बुद्धिमान्मनुष्येषु स युक्तः कृत्स्नकर्मकृत्।।
verses.transliteration:
karmaṇy akarma yaḥ paśyed akarmaṇi ca karma yaḥ
sa buddhimān manuṣyeṣu sa yuktaḥ kṛtsna-karma-kṛt
verses.translation: He who sees inaction in action and action in inaction, he is wise among men. He is a Yogi who is engaged in all activities.
verses.commentary: This is a pivotal and profound verse. Krishna provides the key to understanding the 'gahana gati' (mysterious path) of action. He explains that a truly wise person sees 'akarma' (inaction) in the midst of 'karma' (action) and 'karma' in 'akarma.' This means that true inaction is not physical inactivity but a state of mind where one is detached from the results of their actions. Similarly, even in physical inactivity, one's mind can be full of action. This is a direct answer to Arjuna's dilemma and a definition of a true Karma Yogi.

verses.sanskrit_text:
यस्य सर्वे समारम्भाः कामसङ्कल्पवर्जिताः।
ज्ञानाग्निदग्धकर्माणं तमाहुः पण्डितं बुधाः।।
verses.transliteration:
yasya sarve samārambhāḥ kāma-saṅkalpa-varjitāḥ
jñānāgni-dagdha-karmāṇaṁ tam āhuḥ paṇḍitaṁ budhāḥ
verses.translation: The wise call him a sage whose every endeavor is free from desire and selfish motive. His actions are burnt up by the fire of knowledge.

word_meanings.meaning: free from desire and selfish motive
whose actions are burnt by the fire of knowledge

verses.commentary: Krishna defines a true sage ('paṇḍitaṁ'). It is not someone who gives up action but someone whose actions are 'kāma-saṅkalpa-varjitāḥ' (free from desire and selfish motives). The key concept is the 'jñānāgni' (fire of knowledge) that 'burns up' the 'karma' (actions). This means that the knowledge of the eternal soul and the detachment from results purifies all actions, leaving no karmic residue. This is the goal of a Karma Yogi.

verses.sanskrit_text:
त्यक्त्वा कर्मफलासंगं नित्यतृप्तो निराश्रयः।
कर्मण्यभिप्रवृत्तोऽपि नैव किञ्चित्करोति सः।।
verses.transliteration:
tyaktvā karma-phalāsaṅgaṁ nitya-tṛpto nirāśrayaḥ
karmany abhipravṛtto 'pi naiva kiñcit karoti saḥ
verses.translation: Having abandoned all attachment to the fruits of action, ever-satisfied and independent, he does not do anything, even while engaged in all kinds of activities.

word_meanings.meaning: attachment to the fruits of action

verses.commentary: This verse is a direct application of the 'inaction in action' principle. Krishna describes a person who, despite being 'abhipravṛttaḥ' (fully engaged) in 'karma' (actions), 'naiva kiñcit karoti' (does not do anything). This is because they have abandoned all attachment to the fruits of their actions. They are 'nitya-tṛptaḥ' (ever-satisfied) and 'nirāśrayaḥ' (independent), because their happiness comes from within, not from external results.

verses.sanskrit_text:
निराशीर्यतचित्तात्मा त्यक्तसर्वपरिग्रहः।
शारीरं केवलं कर्म कुर्वन्नाप्नोति किल्बिषम्।।
verses.transliteration:
nirāśīr yata-citta-ātmā tyakta-sarva-parigrahaḥ
śārīraṁ kevalaṁ karma kurvann āpnoti kilbiṣam
verses.translation: Having no desires, a controlled mind and self, and having given up all sense of possession, he does not incur sin by performing actions merely for the body.

word_meanings.meaning: with a controlled mind and self

verses.commentary: Krishna provides another layer to the Karma Yogi's practice. He states that a person who acts without 'āśīḥ' (desires), with a 'yata-citta-ātmā' (controlled mind and self), and has given up 'parigrahaḥ' (possessions) does not incur 'kilbiṣam' (sin). The key is the shift in focus: the action is performed for the 'śārīraṁ kevalaṁ' (merely for the body's maintenance) and not for personal gain. This attitude allows one to be free from the bondage of karma.

verses.sanskrit_text:
यदृच्छालाभसन्तुष्टो द्वन्द्वातीतो विमत्सरः।
समः सिद्धावसिद्धौ च कृत्वापि न निबध्यते।।
verses.transliteration:
yadṛcchā-lābha-santuṣṭo dvandvātīto vimatsaraḥ
samaḥ siddhāv asiddhau ca kṛtvāpi na nibadhyate
verses.translation: Content with whatever comes to him by chance, free from the dualities, not envious, and equanimous in success and failure, he is not bound even while acting.

word_meanings.meaning: content with whatever comes by chance

verses.commentary: Krishna lists the qualities of a person who is free from the bondage of action. They are 'yadṛcchā-lābha-santuṣṭaḥ' (content with what comes by chance), 'dvandvātīto' (transcending dualities), and 'vimatsaraḥ' (without envy). This person is 'samaḥ' (equanimous) in both 'siddhau' (success) and 'asiddhau' (failure). This is the practical definition of a 'Sthitaprajna' (a person of steady wisdom) from Chapter 2, and it shows that this state is achievable through the path of Karma Yoga.

verses.sanskrit_text:
गतसङ्गस्य मुक्तस्य ज्ञानावस्थितचेतसः।
यज्ञायाचरतः कर्म समग्रं प्रविलीयते।।
verses.transliteration:
gata-saṅgasya muktasya jñānāvasthita-cetasaḥ
yajñāyācarataḥ karma samagraṁ pravilīyate
verses.translation: The actions of a person who is free from attachment, who is liberated, and whose mind is established in knowledge, merge completely when performed for the sake of sacrifice.

word_meanings.meaning: of one who is free from attachment
of one whose mind is established in knowledge

verses.commentary: This verse describes the state of a liberated Karma Yogi. When a person performs action for 'Yajña' (sacrifice) and is 'gata-saṅgasya' (free from attachment) and 'muktasya' (liberated), their actions 'pravilīyate' (dissolve) without leaving any karmic residue. This shows that the true goal of Karma Yoga is not just to perform duty, but to do so with an elevated consciousness that leads to the complete dissolution of karma.

verses.sanskrit_text:
ब्रह्मार्पणं ब्रह्म हविर्ब्रह्माग्नौ ब्रह्मणा हुतम्।
ब्रह्मैव तेन गन्तव्यं ब्रह्मकर्मसमाधिना।।
verses.transliteration:
brahmārpaṇaṁ brahma havir brahmāgnau brahmaṇā hutam
brahmaiva tena gantavyaṁ brahma-karma-samādhinā
verses.translation: The act of offering is Brahman, the offering itself is Brahman, it is offered by Brahman into the fire of Brahman. Brahman alone is to be reached by him who is absorbed in the action of Brahman.

word_meanings.meaning: the act of offering is Brahman
by one who is absorbed in the action of Brahman

verses.commentary: This verse is the metaphysical peak of 'Karma Yoga'. Krishna uses the metaphor of 'Yajña' (sacrifice) to explain that when a person is fully absorbed in Brahman, the distinction between the offerer, the offering, the fire, and the action disappears, and everything is seen as Brahman. This is the state of a 'brahma-karma-samādhinā' (one absorbed in the action of Brahman). The goal is not just to act without desire but to act with the full consciousness of the divine nature of all things.

verses.sanskrit_text:
दैवमेवापरे यज्ञं योगिनः पर्युपासते।
ब्रह्माग्नावपरे यज्ञं यज्ञेनैवोपजुह्वति।।
verses.transliteration:
daivam evāpare yajñaṁ yoginaḥ paryupāsate
brahmāgnāv apare yajñaṁ yajñenaivopajuhvati
verses.translation: Some Yogis perform sacrifices to the gods, while others offer the self as a sacrifice into the fire of Brahman, by means of sacrifice itself.
verses.commentary: Krishna begins a series of verses explaining the different types of 'Yajña' (sacrifice). He first contrasts two types of yogis: those who perform rituals for the gods and those who perform a higher, spiritual sacrifice by offering their 'self' into the fire of Brahman. This shows that all actions can be a form of worship, but the motive and the object of the worship determine the quality of the 'Yajña'.

verses.sanskrit_text:
श्रोत्रादीनीन्द्रियाण्यन्ये संयमाग्निषु जुह्वति।
शब्दादीन्विषयानन्य इन्द्रियाग्निषु जुह्वति।।
verses.transliteration:
śrotrādīnīndriyāṇy anye saṁyamāgniṣu juhvati
śabdādīn viṣayān anya indriyāgniṣu juhvati
verses.translation: Some offer their senses, like the hearing organ, into the fire of self-control. Others offer the objects of the senses, like sound, into the fire of the senses.

word_meanings.meaning: into the fires of the senses

verses.commentary: Krishna continues to list different forms of 'Yajña'. He describes two types of practitioners: those who offer their senses into the 'fire of self-control' and those who offer the sense objects into the 'fire of the senses'. The first group is practicing control by not engaging with the sense objects, while the second group is engaging with them in a detached, sacrificial way. Both are considered a form of 'Yajña'.

verses.sanskrit_text:
सर्वाणीन्द्रियकर्माणि प्राणकर्माणि चापरे।
आत्मसंयमयोगाग्नौ जुह्वति ज्ञानदीपिते।।
verses.transliteration:
sarvāṇīndriya-karmāṇi prāṇa-karmāṇi cāpare
ātma-saṁyama-yogāgnau juhvati jñāna-dīpite
verses.translation: Others offer all the actions of the senses and the actions of the vital breath into the fire of Yoga of self-control, which is kindled by knowledge.

word_meanings.meaning: the actions of the vital breath
into the fire of the Yoga of self-control

verses.commentary: Krishna describes a higher form of 'Yajña'. He says that some spiritual practitioners offer all their actions, both of the senses and of the 'prāṇa' (vital breath), into the 'fire of the Yoga of self-control.' This fire is 'jñāna-dīpite' (kindled by knowledge). This is a more advanced practice than simple self-control, as it involves the total purification of all one's actions through spiritual knowledge.

verses.sanskrit_text:
द्रव्ययज्ञास्तपोयज्ञा योगयज्ञास्तथापरे।
स्वाध्यायज्ञानयज्ञाश्च यतयः संशितव्रताः।।
verses.transliteration:
dravya-yajñās tapo-yajñā yoga-yajñās tathāpare
svādhyāya-jñāna-yajñāś ca yatayaḥ saṁśita-vratāḥ
verses.translation: Some, with stern vows, perform sacrifices of wealth, some of austerity, others of Yoga, and yet others of study and knowledge.
verses.commentary: Krishna provides a more exhaustive list of the different types of 'Yajña'. He mentions material offerings ('dravya-yajñāḥ'), physical austerities ('tapo-yajñāḥ'), the practice of Yoga ('yoga-yajñāḥ'), and the study of scriptures and knowledge ('svādhyāya-jñāna-yajñāḥ'). This shows that 'Yajña' is a broad concept that encompasses all forms of disciplined and selfless action, catering to different temperaments and spiritual paths.

verses.sanskrit_text:
अपाने जुह्वति प्राणं प्राणेऽपानं तथापरे।
प्राणापानगती रुद्ध्वा प्राणायामपरायणाः।।
verses.transliteration:
apāne juhvati prāṇaṁ prāṇe 'pānaṁ tathāpare
prāṇāpāna-gatī ruddhvā prāṇāyāma-parāyaṇāḥ
verses.translation: Others offer the outgoing breath into the incoming breath, and the incoming breath into the outgoing breath, restraining the flow of both breaths, and thus become devoted to Pranayama.

word_meanings.meaning: the movements of the incoming and outgoing breaths

verses.commentary: Krishna discusses the 'Yajña' of 'Pranayama' (breath control). He describes the practice of controlling the 'prāṇa' (incoming breath) and 'apāna' (outgoing breath), which leads to a deep state of concentration. This verse shows that even the most physical and physiological processes can be transformed into a spiritual practice. This highlights the all-encompassing nature of 'Karma Yoga', which is not limited to external actions.

verses.sanskrit_text:
अपाने जुह्वति प्राणं प्राणेऽपानं तथापरे।
प्राणापानगती रुद्ध्वा प्राणायामपरायणाः।।
verses.transliteration:
apāne juhvati prāṇaṁ prāṇe 'pānaṁ tathāpare
prāṇāpāna-gatī ruddhvā prāṇāyāma-parāyaṇāḥ
verses.translation: Others, restraining the flow of their vital breaths, offer the outgoing breath into the incoming breath, and the incoming breath into the outgoing breath, and are devoted to Pranayama.

word_meanings.meaning: the movements of the incoming and outgoing breaths

verses.commentary: This verse is a repetition of verse 29, which is common in ancient texts for emphasis. It reiterates the importance of 'Pranayama' as a form of sacrifice. The repetition highlights the significance of breath control as a means to achieve a higher state of consciousness and to perform a deep form of 'Yajña'. It shows that the inner world is just as important as the outer world for spiritual progress.

verses.sanskrit_text:
यज्ञशिष्टासिनः सन्तो मुच्यन्ते सर्वकिल्बिषैः।
भुञ्जते ते त्वघं पापा ये पचन्त्यात्मकारणात्।।
verses.transliteration:
yajña-śiṣṭāśinaḥ santo mucyante sarva-kilbiṣaiḥ
bhuñjate te tv aghaṁ pāpā ye pacanty ātma-kāraṇāt
verses.translation: The righteous who eat the remnants of the sacrifice are freed from all sins; but those sinful ones who cook food solely for their own sake eat only sin.

word_meanings.meaning: those who eat the remnants of the sacrifice

verses.commentary: This verse is an exact repetition of Chapter 3, Verse 13. Krishna uses it here to emphasize that the principle of 'Yajña' is not just about a specific ritual but about the attitude of the person. Whether one is a 'jñāni' (knower) or a 'karma-yogi' (active person), the principle of selfless action and giving back to the universe is the key to liberation and freedom from 'kilbiṣam' (sin).

verses.sanskrit_text:
एवं बहुविधा यज्ञा वितता ब्रह्मणो मुखे।
कर्मजान्विद्धि तान्सर्वानेवं ज्ञात्वा विमोक्ष्यसे।।
verses.transliteration:
evaṁ bahu-vidhā yajñā vitatā brahmaṇo mukhe
karma-jān viddhi tān sarvān evaṁ jñātvā vimokṣyase
verses.translation: All these various forms of sacrifice are spread out in the mouth of Brahman (the Vedas). Know them all to be born of action, and knowing this, you will be liberated.
verses.commentary: Krishna provides a summary of his teachings on 'Yajña'. He states that all these different forms of sacrifice are found in the Vedas and are all 'karma-jān' (born of action). By understanding this profound truth, Arjuna will be 'vimokṣyase' (liberated). This verse brings all the different types of 'Yajña' under a single, unifying principle: action performed with the right attitude is the path to liberation.

verses.sanskrit_text:
श्रेयान्द्रव्यमयाद्यज्ञाज्ज्ञानयज्ञः परन्तप।
सर्वे कर्माखिलं पार्थ ज्ञाने परिसमाप्यते।।
verses.transliteration:
śreyān dravya-mayād yajñāj jñāna-yajñaḥ parantapa
sarvaṁ karmākhilaṁ pārtha jñāne parisamāpyate
verses.translation: The sacrifice of knowledge is superior to the sacrifice of material things, O chastiser of enemies. O son of Pritha, all actions, without exception, culminate in knowledge.

word_meanings.meaning: than that consisting of material things

verses.commentary: Krishna makes a definitive statement on the hierarchy of 'Yajña'. He says that the 'jñāna-yajñaḥ' (sacrifice of knowledge) is superior to the 'dravya-mayād yajñāt' (sacrifice of material things). He explains that all actions, regardless of their nature, ultimately 'parisamāpyate' (culminate) in 'jñāne' (knowledge). This is a crucial point, as it reconciles the paths of Karma Yoga and Jnana Yoga, showing that action is a means to attain knowledge, which is the ultimate goal.

verses.sanskrit_text:
तद्विद्धि प्रणिपातेन परिप्रश्नेन सेवया।
उपदेक्ष्यन्ति ते ज्ञानं ज्ञानिनस्तत्त्वदर्शिनः।।
verses.transliteration:
tad viddhi praṇipātena paripraśnena sevayā
upadekṣyanti te jñānaṁ jñāninas tattva-darśinaḥ
verses.translation: Learn that knowledge by approaching a spiritual teacher, by prostration, by questioning, and by service. The wise seers of truth will instruct you in that knowledge.
verses.commentary: Krishna provides a clear, practical roadmap for how to attain this knowledge. He instructs Arjuna to seek out a 'tattva-darśinaḥ' (seer of truth) and to approach them with 'praṇipātena' (prostration), 'paripraśnena' (questioning), and 'sevayā' (service). This is a crucial verse on the importance of a spiritual teacher ('guru') in a student's journey. It shows that knowledge is not gained through books alone but through a humble and dedicated relationship with a genuine teacher.

verses.sanskrit_text:
यज्ज्ञात्वा न पुनर्मोहमेवं यास्यसि पाण्डव।
येन भूतान्यशेषेण द्रक्ष्यस्यात्मन्यथो मयि।।
verses.transliteration:
yaj jñātvā na punar moham evaṁ yāsyasi pāṇḍava
yena bhūtāny aśeṣeṇa drakṣyasy ātmany atho mayi
verses.translation: Having known this, you will not again fall into such a delusion, O son of Pandu. By this knowledge, you will see all beings completely in your own Self and in Me.
verses.commentary: Krishna explains the transformative power of true knowledge. He promises that this knowledge will not only free Arjuna from his current 'moham' (delusion) but will also give him a new vision. He will see all beings 'aśeṣeṇa' (completely) in his own 'ātmani' (Self) and in Krishna. This is the ultimate state of spiritual realization, where one sees the unity of all life and is completely free from the illusion of separation.

verses.sanskrit_text:
अपि चेदसि पापेभ्यः सर्वेभ्यः पापकृत्तमः।
सर्वं ज्ञानप्लवेनैव वृजिनं सन्तरिष्यसि।।
verses.transliteration:
api ced asi pāpebhyaḥ sarvebhyaḥ pāpa-kṛt-tamaḥ
sarvaṁ jñāna-plavenaiva vṛjinaṁ santariṣyasi
verses.translation: Even if you are the most sinful of all sinners, you will cross over all sin by the raft of knowledge alone.

word_meanings.meaning: by the raft of knowledge alone

verses.commentary: Krishna provides a powerful statement on the redemptive power of knowledge. He states that even the 'pāpa-kṛt-tamaḥ' (most sinful) can be liberated by the 'jñāna-plavena' (raft of knowledge). This is a strong and comforting message that transcends all moral and ethical boundaries. It shows that spiritual liberation is not earned through good deeds alone but is attained through the power of knowledge, which purifies all sins and leads to a higher state of consciousness.

verses.sanskrit_text:
यथैधांसि समिद्धोऽग्निर्भस्मसात्कुरुतेऽर्जुन।
ज्ञानाग्निः सर्वकर्माणि भस्मसात्कुरुते तथा।।
verses.transliteration:
yathaidhāṁsi samiddho 'gnir bhasmasāt kurute 'rjuna
jñānāgniḥ sarva-karmāṇi bhasmasāt kurute tathā
verses.translation: Just as a blazing fire turns firewood to ashes, O Arjuna, so too the fire of knowledge turns all actions to ashes.
verses.commentary: Krishna uses another powerful analogy to describe the purifying power of knowledge. He compares 'jñānāgniḥ' (the fire of knowledge) to a blazing fire that turns all 'karmāṇi' (actions) to ashes. This is a direct answer to Arjuna's fear of sin and karma. It shows that by acting with the right knowledge, one can perform any action without being bound by its karmic consequences. This is a central theme of 'Karma Yoga'.

verses.sanskrit_text:
न हि ज्ञानेन सदृशं पवित्रमिह विद्यते।
तत्स्वयं योगसंसिद्धः कालेनात्मनि विन्दति।।
verses.transliteration:
na hi jñānena sadṛśaṁ pavitram iha vidyate
tat svayaṁ yoga-saṁsiddhaḥ kālenātmani vindati
verses.translation: Indeed, there is nothing in this world as purifying as knowledge. A person who is perfected in Yoga finds that knowledge in due course of time, within himself.

word_meanings.meaning: one who is perfected in Yoga

verses.commentary: Krishna elevates the status of knowledge to the highest form of purification. He states that nothing is as purifying as 'jñāna' (knowledge). He also explains that this knowledge is not external but is found 'svayaṁ' (by himself) and 'ātmani' (within himself) by a person who is 'yoga-saṁsiddhaḥ' (perfected in Yoga). This shows that the path of Karma Yoga is a means to attain this inner, purifying knowledge.

verses.sanskrit_text:
श्रद्धावान्ल्लभते ज्ञानं तत्परः संयतेन्द्रियः।
ज्ञानं लब्ध्वा परां शान्तिमचिरेणाधिगच्छति।।
verses.transliteration:
śraddhāvāḻ labhate jñānaṁ tatparaḥ saṁyatendriyaḥ
jñānaṁ labdhvā parāṁ śāntim acireṇādhigacchati
verses.translation: He who has faith, who is dedicated to it, and who has control over his senses, attains this knowledge. Having attained this knowledge, he soon achieves supreme peace.
verses.commentary: Krishna provides the prerequisites for attaining this knowledge. He states that one must have 'śraddhā' (faith), be 'tatparaḥ' (dedicated), and be 'saṁyatendriyaḥ' (have control over the senses). He promises that a person with these qualities will 'acireṇa' (soon) attain 'parāṁ śāntim' (supreme peace). This verse provides a clear, practical, and hopeful path for Arjuna to follow to overcome his despair and find peace.

verses.sanskrit_text:
अज्ञश्चाश्रद्दधानश्च संशयात्मा विनश्यति।
नायं लोकोऽस्ति न परो न सुखं संशयात्मनः।।
verses.transliteration:
ajñaś cāśraddadhānaś ca saṁśayātmā vinaśyati
nāyaṁ loko 'sti na paro na sukhaṁ saṁśayātmanaḥ
verses.translation: The ignorant, the faithless, and the one with a doubting mind perishes. For a person of a doubting mind, there is neither this world, nor the next, nor happiness.

word_meanings.meaning: the one with a doubting mind
for the one with a doubting mind

verses.commentary: Krishna provides a strong warning about the consequences of doubt and a lack of faith. He states that a 'saṁśaya-ātmā' (a person with a doubting mind) perishes and finds no happiness in this world or the next. This is a direct message to Arjuna, whose despair and confusion are rooted in doubt. Krishna is telling him to let go of his doubt and have faith, which is the necessary first step to spiritual progress.

verses.sanskrit_text:
योगसंन्यस्तकर्माणं ज्ञानसंछिन्नसंशयम्।
आत्मवन्तं न कर्माणि निबध्नन्ति धनञ्जय।।
verses.transliteration:
yoga-saṁnyasta-karmāṇaṁ jñāna-saṁchinna-saṁśayam
ātmavantaṁ na karmāṇi nibadhnanti dhanañjaya
verses.translation: O Dhananjaya, actions do not bind the person who has renounced all actions by Yoga, and whose doubts have been cut asunder by knowledge, and who is established in the Self.

word_meanings.meaning: who has renounced all actions by Yoga
whose doubts are cut asunder by knowledge
who is established in the Self

verses.commentary: Krishna provides the final summary of the chapter's teachings. He states that a person who is free from the bondage of action has three key characteristics: they have 'yoga-saṁnyasta-karmāṇaṁ' (renounced all actions by Yoga), their 'saṁśayam' (doubts) have been 'jñāna-saṁchinna' (cut asunder by knowledge), and they are 'ātmavantaṁ' (established in the Self). This verse beautifully combines all the key themes of the chapter—Karma Yoga, Jnana Yoga, and the importance of Self-realization—into a single, powerful statement of liberation.

verses.sanskrit_text:
तस्मादज्ञानसंभूतं हृत्स्थं ज्ञानासिनात्मनः।
छित्त्वैनं संशयं योगमातिष्ठोत्तिष्ठ भारत।।
verses.transliteration:
tasmād ajñāna-saṁbhūtaṁ hṛt-sthaṁ jñānāsinātmanaḥ
chittvainaṁ saṁśayaṁ yogam ātiṣṭhottiṣṭha bhārata
verses.translation: Therefore, O Bharata, cutting asunder with the sword of knowledge this doubt residing in your heart, which is born of ignorance, stand up and be established in Yoga.
verses.commentary: This concluding verse is Krishna's final command to Arjuna. He tells him to use the 'jñānāsinā' (sword of knowledge) to 'chittvā' (cut asunder) the 'saṁśayam' (doubt) that is in his heart. The command to 'uttiṣṭha' (stand up) is a direct, practical call to action, telling Arjuna to apply the knowledge he has received and resume his duty. This is the moment of transformation, where Arjuna is asked to move from a state of philosophical discussion to a state of enlightened action.
